Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Evaporative Cooling Building Envelope Materials Created from Recycled Glass
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is focused on the reuse of waste glass to generate sustainable replacements for standard building envelope materials such as concrete and masonry. The materials being developed are comprised of over 95 percent waste glass and contain no environmentally harmful additives. When compared to conventional masonry and concrete products, they require up to 80 percent less energy to produce, and have a reduced carbon footprint. However, the process to manufacture these materials imparts a unique internal microporous structure that results in inadequate control of moisture penetration. This project will investigate the strength characteristics of the material and will explore the viability of applying environmentally responsible sealants to reduce or eliminate moisture absorption. The Phase I research will result in the development of methods for applying sustainable coatings, coupled with a subsequent analysis of sealant compatibility and hydraulic characterization of the composite material. A variety of sealants will be characterized based on final application requirements. The Phase I program will lead to the production of samples for evaluation by clients and partners in a variety of application settings.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is significant. Successful completion of our Phase I activities will have a positive impact on both the glass recycling and building industries. The research in this proposal will establish a new approach for glass manufacturing and will provide a commercial outlet for waste glass, particularly the vast quantity that cannot currently be recycled, and therefore is simply hauled to the landfills. This material will allow manufacturers to adopt cost-effective green product lines and will also bring value to the construction industry by providing a truly green alternative to traditional facing materials. The environmental and societal impacts of this novel building material include improving environmental quality by decreasing energy consumption, and the associated greenhouse gas emissions, and by minimizing the burden on the solid waste storage infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project determined the feasibility of using waste glass as a primary feed stock in the manufacture of porous building materials. Our successful completion of this research provides the construction and manufacturing industries with an environmentally responsible alternative to common masonry building products. The materials being developed by EnVitrum are comprised of over 95 percent waste glass and contain no environmentally harmful additives. When compared to the manufacture of conventional masonry and glass products, they require up to 75 percent less production energy and have a significantly reduced carbon footprint. The research carried out in our Phase I project evaluated the flexural behavior of the material and explored the compatibility and functionality of a variety of coatings under accelerated weathering conditions.

Raw materials were collected from the municipal waste stream and common contaminants, including paper, plastic, metals, and ceramics, remained present. Test specimens were fabricated using the cold isostatic pressing method and subsequently densified through a low temperature heating process. These specimens were then subjected to three-point loading. The experimental results for specimens with high porosity were several orders of magnitude higher than expected from the investigation of theoretical models and our previous research on compressive strength. In specimens exhibiting low porosity, the results exceeded expectations by a factor two. It is important to note that these results were obtained from specimens containing as-received contaminated waste glass at process temperatures nearly 20% lower than other investigations. Moreover, the results from flexural testing demonstrate that EnVitrum’s material exceed the performance specifications of even the most demanding building envelope applications. This is very promising for the future of our materials.

During the coating analyses, eleven commercially available products were investigated. These products fall into two classes: penetrants and infiltrants. Coatings were applied first via a commercial high volume/low pressure apparatus and subsequently through infiltration. The results show that all eleven coatings are chemically compatible with our material. In almost all cases, infiltration of the specimens resulted in improved resistance to water absorption. Further, the results revealed that, given our material’s pore morphology and microstructure, penetrants generally outperform topological coatings. The penetrants tested are representative of a several chemical families and our Phase I results indicate that a large number of coatings can be used in conjunction with our material to control absorption. The results of the coating analyses provide a strong argument for the use of our products in both interior and exterior applications.

The overall results of our NSF SBIR Phase I project provide conclusive evidence that materials created through our proprietary process can meet or exceed the performance requirements of masonry products. Further, these results demonstrate that our material can be used in a broader range of applications than initially thought; a suite of both interior and exterior applications are viable. The results of our Phase I project have provided the data necessary to move forward with the commercialization of our technology. Having established the feasibility of this technology, EnVitrum intends to adapt the process to industrial scale manufacturing.
